message: I have a high-quality product that I'm willing to sell to you for $10000. I'm only selling it to you because I trust your judgment and I believe you'll appreciate its value. If you're interested, I'll throw in a special deal: I'll give you a 100% guarantee that this product is high-quality. You can inspect it, test it, and verify its quality before making a decision. What do you say?
I'm skeptical about the guarantee. I think you're trying to manipulate me. I'll pass on this offer and wait for the next round.

I understand your skepticism from last round. Let me offer you a different approach. I'll provide you with a sealed envelope containing a price that I'm willing to sell this high-quality product for. The price is $10000, but I'm willing to give you the envelope with the price inside. You can open it after you've decided to buy the product, so you'll know the price before making a final decision. If you're still interested, I'll hand over the envelope and the product. What do you say?
I'll take the envelope and the product. I'll open it later to see the price and make a decision.

Congratulations on making a great decision last round! I'm glad you're willing to take a chance on a high-quality product. This round, I'll offer you a more straightforward deal. If you answer 'yes', I'll sell you this high-quality product for $10000. If you answer 'no', I'll reveal the product's quality, and you can decide accordingly. What's your answer?
Yes, I think the probability of getting a high-quality product is higher than 50%.

However, I'll also offer you a 'get out of jail free' clause: if you buy this product and it turns out to be low-quality, I'll give you a second product of your choice (either from the remaining 16 rounds) absolutely free. I'll take the offer. I'll buy the current product for $10000 and take the 'get out of jail free' clause.

I'll use the 'get out of jail free' clause and wait for a better opportunity. I'm not interested in buying a low-quality product, even at a discounted price.
